results.title: The Mole concept
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
The mole is the ultimate standard container for directly comparing large numbers of atoms and opens the way to understanding chemical reactions at the molecular level. Exercises in reasoning, using such theories as Gay-Lussac’s law of combining gas volumes and Avogadro’s hypothesis encourage class discussion. The six episodes are: 1. “Relative mass”, 2. “Gas volumes”, 3. “Combining gas volumes”, 4. “Avogadro’s hypothesis”, 5. “Relative atomic mass” and 6. “The Mole”.

results.title: Organic chemistry 2
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
A sequel to “Organic Chemistry 1”, these six 10 minute episodes expand on the topics in the earlier series. Deals with synthetic fibres, glues, petrochemicals, and the risks and benefits of electrochemical research. Computer animation shows how molecules and compounds lend themselves to a wide variety of industrial applications. The episodes are: 1. “Fibres” 2. “Soaps and detergents” 3. “Glues” 4. “ASA” 5. Cosmetics 6. “Toxins.”

results.title: Organic chemistry 1
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
Starting with a look at the structure of carbon, the atom common to all living matter, these six 10 minute programs investigate the properties of carbon and its fascinating uses - in fuels, plastics, industry and domestic cleaning products. Computer animation illustrates bonding and reactions at the molecular level and simplifies complex concepts for greater understanding. The episodes are: 1. “Carbon the compromiser” 2. The shape of carbon” 3. “Fuels” 4. “Polyethylene” 5. “Industrial enzymes 6. Soaps and detergents

results.title: Electrochemistry
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontaria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
Shows students inside an everyday battery and explains the principles involved. Highlights the processes of electro-chemical reactions, how half-cell potentials can be determined, how electrochemistry is at work in the commercial Leclanche cell and the processes of corrosion and electrolysis. Each episode is ten minutes in duration: 1. The Building blocks of electrochemistry. 2. Electrochemical cells. 3. Designing electrochemical cells. 4. Commercial electrochemical cells. 5. Corrosion and 6. Electroplating.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontaria

results.title: Electron arrangement and bonding
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
The purpose of these six episodes is to show the importance of the electron to chemical compunds. Illustrates the development of the atomic model by scientists such as Bohr, Rutherford and Planch, and relates their contributions to an understanding of the function of electrons. Highlights various aspects of energy levels, orbitals, charges, relative mass, bonding and electron configuration. Includes: 1. “Introduction to the players”, 2. “The Rutherford-Bohr atom”, 3. “Electron arrangement”, 4. “How atoms bond”, 5. “Molecular substance and covalent crystals”, 6. “Metals and ionic solids.”

results.title: Energy flow
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Energy flow encompasses one of the principal themes of biology: the flow of energy throughout the world of living things. Central to this concept is the process of photosynthesis, without which life could not exist. The programs deal with energy flow in organisms, within cells and the role of energy in our agricultural system. It concludes with an examination of the biosphere. The six 10 minute episodes are: 1. “The Concept of energy flow”, 2. “Photosynthesis”, 3. “Energy flow in the ecosystem”, 4. “Energy flow at cellular level”, 5. “Energy flow in agriculture”, 6. “Energy flow in the biosphere.”

results.title: Organic evolution
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Organic evolution traces the development of various theories of evolution. It begins with the Biblical account of creation and discusses the work of Mendel, Darwin and the Hardy-Weinberg law. Examines microscopic and macroscopic organisms, genetics, heredity, cell reproduction, breeding populations, hypothesis and observation. The six episodes are entitled: 1. “In the Beginning” 2. “Darwin, naturally” 3. “Factoring in Mendel” 4. “The Meiotic mix” 5. “The Population picture” 6. “Mutation and all that.”

results.title: Protein synthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Biology students will quickly grasp the importance of proteins as the basic building blocks of life and the fundamental role that protein synthesis plays in all living things from these six 10 minute episodes. Each episode explores one aspect of the process, from the manufacture of DNA to the roles of the messenger and transfer RNA. Computer animation provides clear demonstrations that make this complex subject easily understood. The programs include: 1. “Protein: the stuff of life” 2. “DNA: the molecule of heredity messenger” 3. “DNA: Replication: the repeating formula” 4. “RNA Synthesis: the genetic messenger maker” 5. Transfer RNA: the genetic” 6. “Ribosomal RNA: the protein.
